title: Geometric sans with double tier 'a'
content:
Anyone knows the name of this font?  
The image is quite large, scroll sideways to reveal another title.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317070548im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ID%20Font%20Geometric_4760.png)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317070548im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ID%20Font%20Geometric%202_5021.png)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317070548im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ID%20Font%20Geometric%203_4405.png)

Font: 

 Chalet London 1960 

Solved By: 

 [Ryuk](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317070548/http:/typophile.com/user/22675 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [ID Font Geometric.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317070548/http:/typophile.com/files/ID%20Font%20Geometric.png) | 893.87 KB |
author: shironish

comments.content: Hard to say, very Helvetica to me but could be HI [Chalet](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317070548/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/chalet) or [Chalet Book](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317070548/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/chaletbook).
Thanks Ryuk. Yes, it is very Helvetica (similar tittles) but at the same time it's fully geometric (look at the uppercase G). It's a hard one!

Agree with Ryuk. Chalet London 1960 for the heads, and probably Chalet Book for the text (it does have a geometric G):  
 [http://www.houseind.com/fonts/chalet](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317070548/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/chalet "http://www.houseind.com/fonts/chalet")

If you can provide the name of the book, I may be able to confirm....

You're both right, I didn't realise Chalet had different versions, some with a double storey 'a'. I had a look at all their specimens and found the specific version I was after: Chalet London 1960.

Thank you both for your help!
